column2: alice, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
knutt38, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was on Dilantin 300 mg/day plus Mysoline 750 mg/day.  I was on Dilantin for over 35 years with only partial/seizures, blank spells, but only 2 grand mal back 3 decades ago.  I told my neurologist I was having numbness or change in feeling in my feet and legs, ie peripherial neuropathy.  This was accredited to taking Dilantin for so many years and nerve covering damage.  He replaced it with Lyrica with Mysoline and the neuropathy has not progressed.  Two neuro doctors felt this was due to the Dilantin long time use, and once the "offending drug" was removed, I would be better.  I have now been on Lyrica 300mg/day with the above dosage on Mysoline and have continued to be grand mal seizure free.  Do keep your doctor informed if any nerve feeling changes in any part of your body...

column2: badboy257@msn.com, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have taken Dilantin for a little over 2 years now, and although it seems to do a good job of controlling my seizures, it's side effects make me continually want to just give it up.  It's effect on my gums has been painful and horrendous looking, regardless of care attempted. I have had confusion on certain occaisions, and sometimes memory loss is terrible; I've been a residential painter for ten years, and recently could not remember one day if paint is supposed to be applied to outdoor wood thickly or thinly.  Also, until two weeks ago I played guitar 2-3 hours every day, and now I'm finding myself looking up 60-70% of the songs I want to play and still forgetting the chords in the middle of playing.While this drug seems to do a pretty good job of controlling my seizures (at least when I remember to take it often enough to keep my levels up), it's side effects are terrible; it is a dirty drug.  It's great for someone who wears dentures and doesn't ever have to worry about work or normal life outside of the home, but if you want to carry on a normal life without appearing to be a doofus, I wouldn't reccommend it.

column2: DBaker3000, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had epilepsy since I was approx 13 yrs old. I was briefly on Phenobarbital as a child. I was taken off of all meds at the age of approx 18.  I did not have another seizure until I was 24 yrs old.  I have been on Tegretol, but I was far too drowsy to go about my daily life.  I have been on Dilantin for 15 yrs and have been fine. If I miss 1-2 doses I will have a seizure.  I missed about 4 days this week because I had a bad stomach virus.  Yesterday I had a Grand Mal seizsure!!! I have never had this type of seizure.  I honestly thought I was going to meet God yesterday. I found out that Dilantin as rectal suppositories. I am also on the non generic Dilantin which has also made a huge difference. I will NEVER miss a dose again. My gums are just fine. I just keep up with good oral hygiene

column2: Derek, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking 300mg daily of this medication for the past 30 yrs, and it has proven 100% effective in managing my seizures. However, because it causes your gums to receded, you have to be extral diligent in your dental care. Because it also causes a reduction in Vitamin D by the liver, which leads to osteoporosis, I tried to change to lamictal a couple of weeks ago, and it made me REALLY sick. So much so that I switched back to dilantin on my own. Just saw the Dr today and now he wants to try Keppra. I hate the thought of changing medications as it has taken me 30yrs to compensate for the side effects of dilantin. But it really has proven to be "old faithful" for me.

column9: It took a while to get use to it.At first,my levels were out of wack alot,I got very sick,often.Had to go to er on several occasions.It has relived my seizures some.But,I have had a few while being on this medication.It does make me very sleepy alot.But,I prefer to keep giving it a chance instead of switching to a different medicine right now. column2: jeslol36@aim.com, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I had a seizure at the age of 16. Got put on 1-300mg Dilantin a day. My next seizure was at the age of-18. Then the age of-22. Then at the age of 25, course I was then up to 1-500mg of Dilantin a day. At 28 yrs. old, get yanked off of Dilantin. I was told anytime I felt weird, to grab a "candy-bar @ a coke." I was told my seizures were caused by, "stress, low blood sugar levels. And mostly by "water in the back of my head- caused by a blow to the head when I was really young." And I was fine for awhile, actually felt great too. Hopefully at least one of ya'll is still awake. I sure enjoyed writing this "brief description."

column2: Donner, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My seizures are still occuring even though I am taking my meds.

column2: tiger, 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: My husband was put on dilantin twice a day after a seizure due to lesions on his brain, but the level was too low even though he didn't have another one and was put on three capsules a day. What I see is, he is very sleepy all the time, has loss of memory and problems with walking.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Dilantin for about a year now.  I have had a few side effects from this medication.  Since being on this medication my dreams are crazy and very vivid.  I have the same dreams a lot.  I have also experienced memory loss, which is very frustuting.  Before starting this medication I could remember anything.  Now I can't even remember if I've taken my medication, so I started checking it off on the calander.  Overall, Dilantin has been very helpful.  I missed a few doses a few months ago and I went into three seizures, one right after the other, my dilantin level had dropped.  My advice would be to take this medication as prescribed and if you have memory loss and can't remember it, write down when you're supposed to take it and check it off.

column2: dee, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was put on Dilantin when I was 13 years old for petitmal seizures.I wasn't fully controlled and had brainsurgery when I was 16.I was taking 3 different kinds of medicine 4x aday.Dilantin,Phenobarbital and Tegretol.After the surgery I only continued taking Dilantin.I have had no side effects from it and have been on it for 30 years.I also have 2 healthy sons while taking this medicine.

column2: slaptbysara, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had only 1 seizures while pregnant and started taking Dilantin, then also discovered that I had complex partial seizures that I believed was anxiety attacks. I stopped taking Dilantin once for about 6 months and then had another seizure in February 2009. It has even treated my so-called "anxiety attacks" (I still call them that as they don't feel like seizures at all! It's more like dazing off staring in a deja vouz moment.) I urge anyone who thinks they have these and believe they are only anxiety, if you have gone to a therapist of any sort, go to a NEUROLOGIST! I had been going to a therapist about it for months and he could never figure it out. I decided to just deal with it and then a year or so later, mentioned something about anxiety to my neurologist, and when I explained them, and as soon as I said deja vouz he said "no that sounds like a seizure." As much as I didn't want to hear that, I was happy that I had finally found something to really help me!!

column2: dylrose, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: brewcrew1, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had had about 80 -100 seizures during the night until my fiance noticed me having one about 10:00 p.m. We went to the emergency room and I was immediately put on dilantin twice a day. I had 3 more seizures in a one week period until my doc discovered there was not enough in my system so I was placed on 3 a day.  I have not had any since then but the medication keeps me wide awake 24/7 so i was also placed on xanax. The dilantin has caused me severe vomiting on very hit and miss occasions.  I have only been on it since Jan 31, 2009 and just went for my EEG yesterday (3-23-09). We are still exploring what is causing these episodes as I was a very normal, healthy 26 yr. old. Would like to hear from others with similar side effects so I knoe\w there is hope out there. Thank you everyone!

column2: kathy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Though I've been seizure-free since being on Dilantin, I'm not sure I'm willing to put up with the side-effects that I've experienced.  I don't feel as though I can think as clearly, feel somewhat lethargic and my bones ache.  Not the joints, just the long bones of the arms and legs.  I developed a problem with Vitamin D absorption and have to take 2400IU/day for the level to reach the "normal" range.  Bone density tests came out fine, so my doctor's satisfied with keeping me on Dilantin.  I like being seizure-free, but I'd also like it if my bones didn't hurt and if I could feel like my mind wasn't leaving me.

column2: Dudleyroo, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had seizures for 35 years and been on every medication available. You name it, I've tried it... (Liquid, Capsule, Etc.)I have basically been on Dilantin for 27 years. Dilantin is the ONLY medication that really keeps my "petite mal" seizures under control which are usually the most difficuly to control. (from what I have been told by neurologists around the USA.)It does cause unusual gum tissue growth so I have to have my gum tissue trimmed back every 10 years or so but it is well worth it to not have seizures.I tried the generic and it too controled the seizures and I do not think it caused the gum growth...or if it did, it grew slower in comparison when on Dilantin.Bad news about generic was it really began discolaring the "whites" of my eyes, turning them more and more yellow which is why I decided to switch back to the Dilantin. While the yellowing of the eyes and gum growth is supposed to be a possible side affect for BOTH medications, I decided my eyes are more important to me than my gums. In the 20+ years I took the real brand name "Dilantin" I NEVER noticed my eyes turning yellow. While it is not cheap and certainly not pleasant, I can handle getting my gums trimmed every 10 years or so, but I only have the two eyes.Anyways, while rather expensive, Dilantin is a good drug and does a job that no other drug can do. Control my seizure condition which was caused by a "tubor" (a benign, non-malignant, non-life threatening, tumor)in my "corpus colosum" of my brain.

column2: Heidi, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: jodief451, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have taken this drug for over 15 years. I have changed to others several times due to the severe headaches it causes. My Dr. either did not read my labs correct or something, but he had increased my dosage from 300 mg to 600 mg daily. I could not walk or see for several weeks and assumed I had a stroke, after falling and going to the hospital, it was discovered that my level was 49. Normal levels are 10-20. My vision still isn't fully correct. If your Dr. attempts to increase your dosage based on your levels, ask for a second level before increasing it. Make sure your Dr treats you and your symptoms and not your Dilantin level. Some people do fine with a lower level. This is a very good medication for seizures, but also a very dangerous one.

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I started having seizures when I was 13 yrs old, I am now 52 yrs old. I have taken dilantin since the beginning and it has worked great for me. I went from having siezures refularly to, at first, only having one every 3-6 months. Then, it was a year between and now they are controlled. I have had VERY few bad effects from it. Once in a while my gums swell but that is usually when the blood levels are high. I had heard a LOT of negative things that "COULD" happen due to dilantin. When I asked ANY doctor if they could say that any other seizure medication would not have the same effects, they all had to say no...as Dilantin has been used and studied the most of all seizure medication. I have had 2 kids, neither had seizures. For people with epilrpsy, I would highly recommend at least trying dilantin to help controlling them.

column1: Prevention of Seizures following Head Injury or Surgery
column2: CRICKET, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I received as brain injury at the hands of an abusive spouse and for 25 years had seizures.  I tried several medications and went to 32 neurologists before I found someone who could diagnose the problem.  In 1995 I went to Houston, 8 very good doctors located the problem through extensive testing and operated to take the injured part of the brain off (you only use 62% of your brain) and it has been 13 years since the surgery.  I have taken Dilanton 100 mg every day and it has been very effective.  I still take the medication, not because I have seizures anymore but because I don't want to rock the boat and start having them again.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: My Father took Dilantin for a little over a month in 2004. We were warned that he could develop a "rash." He was going through Chemo and radiation at the time, so I thought his burning was side effects from the cancer treatments. In less than a month his face started to look like someone had taken a torch to it. His neck was oozing and the skin just sloughing off. He ended up in the hospital for 11 weeks with about 8 doctors trying ot figure it out. After the first 2 weeks in ICU, I talked the doctor into taking him off all seizure medicines. I didn't think he needed them to start with. Finally a doctor asked me if anyone had suggested "Stephens Johnson Syndrome" I had never heard of it but went online and checked it out. I firmly believe he had it and with God's grace survived DILANTIN!!!

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have taken Dilantin for a few years, and have not had a seizure while on the medication. The only thing I have noticed is that while taking the medication, I tend to become tired moreso all of the time, less enthusiastic, and somewhat depressed.

column2: nilpud@aol.com, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I am 43 years old and have been on dilantin for 27 years, following a sezure disorder attack. and i have very little problems with this drug, i only wish some day i would not have to take this medication anymore
This is the only product that I've been able to take successfully to control my seizures.

column2: Nancyann, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Appears to cause drowsiness. Most side effects have been experienced but are confused with uther medications and treatments for lung cancer and brain tumors.

column2: diane, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: After being of Dilantin for 5 yrs., I found out I had osteoporosis, with 3 spinal fractures and pain throughout my body.  I was never told that this Dilantin would cause any kind of bone problems or interfere with calcium absorbion.  Nothing was mentioned regarding vitamin D, or anything having to do with my bones at all. Now I have to go on some kind of bone therapy.So, fat Fosomax made me sick to my stomach. I waiting on a new med that you take by injection once a year.  I'm looking into it.
